7.60.text:
Alright. First rule of
pizza delivery - never go inside.

12.28.text:
- Oh, hi! Come on in!
- Whoa!

25.84.text:
Are you ready
for your very first job?

28.24.text: No matter what job you get,

29.84.text:
you'll soon have the
freedom of your first pay.

31.84.text:
What you do with the cash
is up to you.

35.20.text: My first job was working at Coles.

37.00.text:
I did one day of
door-to-door knocking.

39.80.text: At a fish shop washing dishes.

49.32.text:
But if you blow your entire
pay on partying,

51.64.text:
how are you going to have
the cash for that festival ticket?

53.92.text:
Or a Christmas
present for your gran?

56.32.text:
As someone once said,
ìIn this crazy world,

58.24.text:
"there are only two things
that are certain: Death and taxes."

62.12.text: When you work, you usually pay tax.

64.56.text:
That tax money goes to
the government

66.40.text:
to pay for things like hospitals,
schools and public transport.

70.88.text:
When you get your first pay, you'll
notice some money has gone to tax.

74.48.text:
Your pay slip shows you how much
you get paid, how much tax you pay

78.20.text:
and how much superannuation,
or super, you get paid.

81.36.text:
Now, if you donít receive a regular
pay slip from your boss,

86.48.text: Yeah, we get pay slips online.

87.76.text:
Iíve had to sort of pay more attention
to them in the past

90.68.text:
when problems have happened,
or I haven't clocked in

92.56.text:
or I haven't clocked off and I haven't
been paid hours,

94.36.text: and so Iíve got to, you know...

95.72.text:
It's really important to keep
on top of that

98.48.text:
on money that youíve
worked really hard for

100.00.text:
and you won't even know about it
'cause you'll be like,

104.20.text:
So, how would you like a chunk
of money in the future?

107.64.text:
Well,
thatís essentially what super is.

110.28.text:
Super is money being
saved for you for when you're older

114.84.text: I have no idea about superannuation.

117.04.text: I know that gets taken away,

118.20.text:
but I don't know
what happens with it,

120.12.text: or, like, what super fund I'm with.

122.24.text:
Uh, I guess I would describe super
as an investment for your future

126.04.text:
when you're finished working
and you're heading into retirement.

128.76.text:
I think it's fantastic.
I mean, if you...

131.32.text:
Essentially itís just a certain amount
of your pay cheque

136.20.text:
and I guess you canít really touch it
until you get to a certain age

143.32.text:
and your boss has to put a minimum
amount into your super fund.

147.84.text:
At 17, he just started
work at the pizza place.

150.92.text:
His employer starts to put away
a little bit of super money for him

154.92.text:
Over time, Nick works
a number of different jobs

157.08.text:
and his super balance
continues to grow.

159.12.text:
Nick can even add to his own
super to make sure

161.60.text:
he has enough to live on
when he retires.

179.04.text:
So what can you do to make
sure your first job works out OK?

183.36.text:
If you'd already gone
through all this,

184.92.text:
you'd know how to avoid those
rookie errors, right?

187.68.text:
So, pizza delivery Nick,
meet Nick the manager.

196.08.text:
When you're starting out,
you have to look, listen and learn.

199.12.text:
And do some extra
tasks around the place.

202.28.text: Don't I just turn up and get paid?

205.20.text:
Mate, you're gonna need to know
what's expected of you.

207.32.text: The boss will go through your duties

208.76.text:
and he'll set you some
short- and long-term goals.

211.32.text:
You've got to know what your rights
and conditions are.

214.32.text:
Oh, and, uh, you should be getting
paid on a regular basis.

218.36.text: Oh, and um, one more thing.

221.36.text:
Don't eat the pizza
thatís at the back of the fridge.

223.80.text:
It's been there
since last yearís Christmas party.

229.64.text:
You should definitely avoid
getting food poisoning.

233.08.text:
As an employee,
you also have other rights at work.

236.00.text:
Your employer has to make sure
you have a safe place to work,

239.00.text:
and of course you should get paid
the right amount.

241.68.text:
Fair Work Australia sets
minimum wage rates

243.92.text:
for different types of jobs
and workers.

245.84.text:
It's illegal for you to be paid less
than the minimum wage rate.

250.24.text:
If I found out my boss was
ripping me off,

252.60.text: I wouldn't have any idea where to go.

254.52.text:
First of all,
I would confront them about it,

256.76.text:
or one of the other managers,
and just tell them what's going on.

261.84.text: Hopefully they can sort it out.

264.80.text:
If you signed a contract or
agreement before starting your job

268.24.text:
and you think you're being paid
less than the legal amount

272.36.text:
you can contact
the Fair Work Ombudsman

274.36.text: to get some advice on what to do.

279.32.text:
When I first started
delivering pizzas,

281.52.text:
I didn't have a contract
or anything in writing.

283.88.text:
I saw the job sign in the pizza shop
window and I just walked right in.

288.32.text:
The boss said
Iíd get paid 12 bucks an hour.

290.80.text:
Wasn't until six months later that
I realised I was getting ripped off.

294.28.text:
I should have been getting
much more.

300.88.text:
If you think youíre not being
paid enough,

302.92.text:
start by finding out
the standard pay in your industry

305.68.text:
for someone of your age
and qualifications.

307.96.text:
You can contact your union
or the relevant industry body.

311.52.text:
You can also ask people who
work in the same industry as you,

314.96.text:
or simply check out the pay
offered in ads for jobs like yours.

318.40.text:
Thereís also
some free financial help available

339.20.text: Now, Nick, you're gonna love this.

341.36.text:
Make sure you set a budget every
pay day and then put $100

345.16.text:
into a separate bank account, and
then in exactly six months, go to...

360.44.text:
And if you do want
the latest technology,

362.36.text:
you've just got to set yourself
a savings target

365.64.text:
You might also want to buy bigger
things in the future,

368.04.text: like a car or even a house.

370.04.text:
And now that you've got
regular income,

371.84.text: these things can be a reality.

373.40.text:
One of the best ways to
get in control of your money

377.72.text: is to do some maths yourself.

379.56.text:
You can jump on to
the MoneySmart website,

384.00.text:
to see where your money's going
and how you can save more.

386.68.text:
Now, don't forget -
you are in control of your own life.

390.32.text:
And now that you're working,
you can buy the things you need...

394.40.text: ..like a pair of good running shoes

396.08.text:
to get away from
those sticky situations.

398.64.text: Youíll find more info on starting work
